functions application network functions we sometimes jokingly refer to as layer
8 above even what the application does
or you could think of it as layer seven-and-a-half if you want and and the
goal of a service mission is to automate a lot of things that people have formally written code around the canonical example I always use is retry
logic what do you do when a call fails this is typically has been left to one
of two things either developers write code about this I have certainly in my own lifetime done this dozens of times
written what happens when when a call fails what do you do do you do you back off do you do an exponential back-off do
you add jitter into that how many times do you do it that sort of behavior is
the sort of behavior that a service mesh aims to automate so developers no longer
need to write that code and that applies for for routing decisions it applies for
circuit braking it applies for rate limiting it applies for a whole host of features I've got a list later on but it
doesn't want to automate those but the key part to a service mesh is that it automates those in a transparent and
language independent way transparent meaning the developer doesn't have to
write any code to use a service mesh developer doesn't have to when we first
announced this to you I was at a conference and I overheard some people saying Oh Google and IBM invented the
service bus and and the huge difference between a service bus and a service mesh is a service bus is something you code
to you put messages on it you use its API it delivers those messages a service mesh is transparent developers place
calls to other systems and the service mesh transparently and in a language independent way takes
care of that functionality and what I mean by language independent is you don't need to embed a client library in
your source code you don't need to compile something in any anytime you do
that of course those those things are implemented in language independent fashions and a lot of what we talk about with this you could be accomplished
using existing technologies if you choose a certain language tag if you're

based work there are three main things at the core of what sto gives you
observability control and security and by observability I mean what's going on
in this application an application as I said before is now a complex thing often many many services could be dozens it
could be hundreds depending on on who you are how long you been doing this and
sto has a general goal of helping to understand your application the first
thing it does and and and this this may seem like table stakes but a lot of people just don't have this and collects

at Google the golden signals if you've read the Google that's our ebook you know what these are the first three are traffic for a
service error rates and latency and various percentiles sto grabs all of
those and and sends them to the system of your choice that lets you monitor essentially
service level indicators for every service too often every service that someone brings up in an organization
decides on their own what their what their SL eyes will be there's no uniformity there it's very difficult you
can't build a standard dashboard so so we believe very strongly and sure you can you can monitor app specific metrics
if you want to that's great but you should start with a twith a a uniform set of golden signals we also
collect logs and traces from your app so we believe in collecting blogs on on every call sometimes people ask us so
what percentage of the calls do you log we believe very strongly in logging off we don't keep logs for very long but we
believe strongly in logging them and and having tracing built into to your app so
that you can run tracing on a representative sample of those understanding the state of your service
is you know signals are important for that understanding what happened when something goes wrong you need to
understand why you need to root out latency problems being able to have
those logs and traces are very important finally I clear clearly mapping service

driving people to to use do was the ability to easily understand where their

services and then the last is is security and SEO offers the ability to
add MPLS in on on your interest service traffic MPLS means every service gets an
identity and every call placed from that service will have cryptographically
secure tokens that indicate who's placing that call once you have a strong identity on a call that means you can
then have an authorization policy to say oh do I trust this we hope that in the
future people move from IP based security models to service identity
based security models we've done this at Google we think it's a both leads to a
more secure network as well as a network that's easier to administer easier to operate our architecture is we install a

configuration around it does integrate with service registries aside from

client-side proxies know how to route their traffic mixer is is what makes SEO
a platform and not just a service mesh and that is a set of API s that allow at
